SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Why, there it is; he has no money, that's true; but then, as he never said no to any request in his life, he has given them a bill drawn by a friend of his upon a merchant in the city, which I am to get chang'd; for you must know that I am to go with them to Scotland myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: It seems the young gentleman is obliged to take a different road from his mistress, as he is to call upon an uncle of his that lives out of the way, in order to prepare a place for their reception, when they return; so they have borrowed me from my master, as the properest person to attend the young lady down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: To the land of matrimony! A pleasant journey, Jarvis.

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Ay, but I'm only to have all the fatigues on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Well, it may be shorter, less fatiguing, than you imagine. I know but too much of the young lady's family and connexions, whom I have
seen abroad. I have also discover'd that Miss Rich∣land is not indifferent to my thoughtless nephew; and he endeavours, tho' I fear, in vain, to establish that connexion. But, come, the letter I wait for must be almost finish'd; I'll let you further into my intentions, in the next room.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT THE FOURTH.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Well, sure the devil's in me of late, for running my head into such defiles, as nothing but a genius like my own could draw me from. I was formerly contented to husband out my places and pensions with some degree of frugality; but, curse it, of late I have given away the whole Court Register in less time than they could print the title page; yet, hang it, why scruple a lie or two to come at a fine girl, when I every day tell a thousand for nothing. Ha! Honeywood here before. Could Miss Richland have set him at liberty?

Mr. Honeywood, I'm glad to see you abroad again. I find my concurrence was not necessary in your unfortunate affairs. I had put things in a train to do your business; but it is not for me to say what I intended doing.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: It was unfortunate indeed, Sir. But what adds to my uneasiness is, that while you seem to be acquainted with my misfortune, I, myself, continue still a stranger to my benefactor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: How! not know the friend that served you?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Can't guess at the person.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Enquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I have, but all I can learn is, that he chuses to remain concealed, and that all enquiry must be fruitless.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Must be fruitless?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Absolutely fruitless.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Sure of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Honyw.
SP.P: Very sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Then I'll be damn'd if you shall ever know it from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: How, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: I suppose now, Mr. Honeywood, you think my rent-roll very considerable, and that I have vast sums of money to throw away; I know you do. The world to be sure says such things of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: The world, by what I learn, is no stran∣ger to your generosity But where does this tend?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: To nothing; nothing in the world. The town, to be sure, when it makes such a thing as me the subject of conversation, has asserted, that I never yet patronized a man of merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I have heard instances to the contrary, even from yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Yes, Honeywood, and there are instances to the contrary, that you shall never hear from myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Ha, dear Sir, permit me to ask you but one question.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Sir, ask me no questions: I say, Sir, ask me no questions; I'll be damn'd, if I answer them.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I will ask no further. My friend, my be∣nefactor, it is, it must be here, that I am indebted for freedom, for honour. Yes, thou worthiest of men, from the beginning I suspected it, but was afraid to return thanks; which, if undeserved, might seem reproaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: I protest I don't understand all this, Mr. Honeywood. You treat me very cavalierly. I do assure you, Sir.—Blood, Sir, can't a man be permitted to enjoy the luxury of his own feelings without all this parade?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Nay, do not attempt to conceal an action that adds to your honour. Your looks, your air, your manner, all confess it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P:
Confess it! Sir. Torture itself, Sir, shall never bring me to confess it. Mr. Honeywood, I have admitted you upon terms of friendship. Don't let us fall out; make me happy, and let this be buried in oblivion. You know I hate ostentation;
you know I do. Come, come, Honeywood, you know I always lov'd to be a friend, and not a patron. I beg this may make no kind of distance between us. Come, come, you and I must be more familiar—Indeed we must.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Heavens! Can I ever repay such friend∣ship! Is there any way! Thou best of men, can I ever return the obligation?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: A bagatelle, a mere bagatelle. But I see your heart is labouring to be grateful. You shall be grateful. It would be cruel to disappoint you.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: How! Teach me the manner. Is there any way?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: From this moment you're mine. Yes, my friend, you shall know it—I'm in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: And can I assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Nobody so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: In what manner? I'm all impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: You shall make love for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: And to whom shall I speak in your favour?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: To a lady with whom you have great in∣terest, I assure you. Miss Richland.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Miss Richland!

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Yes, Miss Richland. She has struckthe blow up to the hilt, in my bosom, by Jupiter.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Heavens! was ever any thing more un∣fortunate! It is too much to be endur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Unfortunate indeed! And yet I can endure it, till you have opened the affair to her for me. Between ourselves, I think she likes me. I'm not apt to boast, but I think she does.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Indeed! But do you know the person you apply to?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Yes, I know you are her friend and mine: that's enough. To you, therefore, I commit the success of my passion. I'll say no more, let friend∣ship do the rest. I have only to add, that if at any time my little interest can be of service—but, hang it, I'll make no promises—you know my interest is your's at any time. No apologies, my friend, I'll not be answered, it shall be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Open, generous, unsuspecting man! He little thinks that I love her too; and with such an ar∣dent passion!—But then it was ever but a vain and hopeless one. My torment, my persecution, what shall I do! Love, friendship, a hopeless passion, a deserving friend! Love, that has been my tor∣mentor; a friend, that has, perhaps, distress'd him∣self, to serve me. It shall be so. Yes, I will dis∣card the fondling hope from my bosom, and exert all my influence in his favour. And yet to see her in the possession of another!—Insupportable. But then to betray a generous, trusty friend!—Worse, worse, Yes, I'm resolv'd. Let me but be the instrument of their happiness, and then quit a country, where I must for ever despair of finding my own.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter OLIVIA and GARNET, who carries a Milliner's Box.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Dear me, I wish this journey were over. No news of Jarvis yet? I believe the old peevish creature delays purely to vex me.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, Madam, I did hear him say, a little snubbing before marriage, would teach you to bear it the better afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: To be gone a full hour, tho' he had only to get a bill changed in the city! How provoking!

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: I'll lay my life, Mr. Leontine, that had twice as much to do, is setting off by this time from his inn; and here you are left behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Well, let us be prepar'd for his coming, however. Are you sure you have omitted nothing, Garnet?

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: Not a stick, madam—all's here. Yet I wish you could take the white and silver to be mar∣ried in. It's the worst luck in the world, in any thing but white. I knew one Bett Stubbs, of our town, was married in red; and, as sure as eggs is eggs, the bridegroom and she had a miff before morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: No matter. I'm all impatience till we are out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: Bless me, madam, I had almost forgot the wedding ring!—The sweet little thing—I don't think it would go on my little finger. And what if I put in a gentleman's night cap, in case of necessity, madam? But here's Jarvis.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: O, Jarvis, are you come at last? We have been ready this half hour. Now let's be going. Let us fly!

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Aye, to Jericho; for we shall have no go∣ing to Scotland this bout, I fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: How! What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Money, money, is the matter, Madam. We have got no money. What the plague do you send me of your fool's errand for? My master's bill upon the city is not worth a rush. Here it is, Mrs. Garnet may pin up her hair with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Undone! How could Honeywood serve us so! What shall we do? Can't we go without it?

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Go to Scotland without money! To Scotland without money! Lord how some people understand geography! We might as well set sail for Patagonia upon a cork jacket.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Such a disappointment! What a base in∣sincere man was your master, to serve us in this manner. Is this his good nature?

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Nay, don't talk ill of my master, Madam. I won't bear to hear any body talk ill of him but myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: Bless us! now I think on't, Madam, you need not be under any uneasiness, I saw Mr. Leon∣tine receive forty guineas from his father just before he set out, and he can't yet have left the inn. A short letter will reach him there.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Well remember'd, Garnet; I'll write im∣mediately. How's this! Bless me, my hand trem∣bles so I can't write a word. Do you write, Garnet; and, upon second thought it will be better from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P:
Truly, madam, I write and indite but poorly. I never was kute at my larning. But I'll do
what I can to please you. Let me see. All out of my own head, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Whatever you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: (Writing.) Muster Croaker. Twenty guineas, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Ay, twenty will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: At the bar of the Talbot till call'd for. Expedition—will be blown up.—All of a flame. Quick, dispatch—Cupid, the little God of Love—I conclude it, madam, with Cupid, I love to see a love letter end like poetry.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Well, well, what you please, any thing. But how shall we send it? I can trust none of the fervants of this family.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: Odso, Madam, Mr. Honeywood's butler is in the next room; he's a dear, sweet man; he'll do any thing for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: He! the dog, he'll certainly commit some blunder. He's drunk and sober ten times a day.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: No matter. Fly, Garnet; any body we can trust will do. [Exit Garnet.] Well, Jarvis, now we can have nothing more to interrupt us. You may take up the things, and carry them on to the inn. Have you no hands, Jarvis?

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Soft and fair, young lady. You, that are going to be married, think things can never be done too fast: but we that are old, and know what we are about, must elope methodically, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Well, sure, if my indiscretions were to be done over again—

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: My life for it you would do them ten times over.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Why will you talk so? If you knew how unhappy they make me—

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Very unhappy, no doubt: I was once just as unhappy when I was going to be married myself. I'll tell you a story about that—

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: A story! when I'm all impatience to be away. Was there ever such a dilatory creature!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P:
Well, Madam, if we must march, why we will march; that's all. Tho', odds bobs we have still
forgot one thing we should never travel without—a case of good razors, and a box of shaving-powder. But no matter, I believe we shall be pretty well shaved in Scotland.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: Undone, undone, Madam. Ah, Mr. Jarvis, you said right enough. As sure as death Mr. Honeywood's rogue of a drunken butler, drop'd the letter before he went ten yards from the door. There's old Croaker has just pick'd it up, and is this moment reading it to himself in the hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Unfortunate! We shall be discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Garnet.
SP.P: No, Madam: don't be uneasy, he can make neither head nor tail of it. To be sure he looks as if he was broke loose from Bedlam about it, but he can't find what it means for all that. O Lud, he is coming this way all in the horrors!

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Then let us leave the house this instant, for fear he should ask farther questions. In the mean time, Garnet, do you write and send off just such another.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Death and destruction! Are all the hor∣rors of air, fire and water to be levelled only at me! Am I only to be singled out for gunpowder-plots, combustibles and conflagration! Here it is—An in∣cendiary letter drop'd at my door. To Muster Croaker, these, with speed. Ay, ay, plain enough the di∣rection: all in the genuine incendiary spelling, and as cramp as the devil. With speed. O, confound your speed. But let me read it once more.

Mustar Croakar as sone as yoew see this leve twenty gunnes at the bar of the Talboot tell caled for or yowe and yower experetion will be al blown up: Ah, but too plain. Blood and gunpowder in every line of it. Blown up! murderous dog! All blown up! Hea∣vens! what have I and my poor family done, to be all blown up! (reads.) Our pockets are low, and mo∣ney we must have. Ay, there's the reason; they'll
blow us up, because they have got low pockets. (Reads.) It is but a short time you have to consider; for if this takes wind, the house will quickly be all of a flame. Inhuman monsters! blow us up, and then burn us. The earthquake at Lisbon was but a bon∣fire to it. (Reads.) Make quick dispatch, and so no more at present. But may Cupid, the little God of Love, go with you wherever you go. The little God of Love! Cupid, the little God of Love go with me! Go you to the devil, you and your little Cupid together; I'm so frightned, I scarce know whether I sit, stand, or go. Perhaps this moment I'm treading on lighted matches, blazing brimstone and barrels of gunpowder. They are preparing to blow me up into the clouds. Murder! We shall be all burnt in our beds; we shall be all burnt in our beds.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Murder's the matter. We shall be a blown up in our beds before morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: I hope not, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: What signifies what you hope, Madam, when I have a certificate of it here in my hand. Will nothing alarm my family! Sleeping and eating, sleeping and eating is the only work from morning till night in my house. My insensible crew could sleep, tho' rock'd by an earthquake; and fry beef steaks at a volcano.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: But, Sir, you have alarmed them so often already, we have nothing but earthquakes, famines, plagues and mad dogs from year's end to year's end. You remember, Sir, it is not above a month ago, you assur'd us of a conspiracy among the bakers, to poison us in our bread; and so kept the whole family a week upon potatoes.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P:
And potatoes were too good for them. But why do I stand talking here with a girl, when I should be facing the enemy without? Here, John, Nicodemus, search the house. Look into the cellars, to see if there be any combustibles below; and above,
in the apartments, that no matches be thrown in at the windows. Let all the fires be put out, and let the engine be drawn out in the yard, to play upon the house in case of necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: What can he mean by all this? Yet, why should I enquire, when he alarms us in this manner almost every day! But Honeywood has de∣sired an interview with me in private. What can he mean; or, rather, what means this palpitation at his approach! It is the first time he ever shewed any thing in his conduct that seem'd particular. Sure he cannot mean to—but he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I presum'd to solicit this interview, Ma∣dam, before I left town, to be permitted—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Indeed! Leaving town, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Yes, Madam; perhaps the kingdom. I have presumed, I say, to desire the favour of this interview—in order to disclose something which our long friendship prompts. And yet my fears—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: His fears! What are his fears to mine!
We have indeed been long acquainted, Sir; very long. If I remember, our first meeting was at the French ambassador's.—Do you recollect how you were pleas'd to rally me upon my complexion there?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Perfectly, madam; I presum'd to reprove you for painting: but your warmer blushes soon convinc'd the company, that the colouring was all from nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: And yet you only meant it, in your good natur'd way, to make me pay a compliment to myself. In the same manner you danc'd that night with the most aukward woman in company, because you saw nobody else would take her out.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Yes; and was rewarded the next night, by dancing with the finest woman in company, that every body wish'd to take out.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Well, Sir, if you thought so then, I fear your judgment has since corrected the errors of a first impression. We generally shew to most advan∣tage at first. Our sex are like poor tradesmen, that put all their best goods to be seen at the windows.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: The first impression, Madam, did indeed deceive me. I expected to find a woman with all the faults of conscious flattered beauty. I expected to find her vain and insolent. But every day has since taught me that it is possible to possess sense without pride, and beauty without affectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: This, Sir, is a style very unusual with Mr. Honeywood; and I should be glad to know why he thus attempts to encrease that vanity, which his own lessons taught me to despise.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I ask pardon, Madam. Yet, from our long friendship, I presumed I might have some right to offer, without offence, what you may refuse with∣out offending.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Sir! I beg you'd reflect; tho', I fear, I shall scarce have any power to refuse a request of yours; yet, you may be precipitate: consider, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I own my rashness; but, as I plead the cause of friendship, of one who loves.—Don't be alarmed, Madam.—Who loves you with the most ardent passion; whose whole happiness is placed in you—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: I fear, Sir, I shall never find whom you mean, by this description of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Ah, Madam, it but too plainly points him out. Tho' he should be too humble himself to urge his pretensions, or you too modest to understand them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Well; it would be affectation any lon∣ger to pretend ignorance; and, I will own, Sir, I have long been prejudiced in his favour. It was but na∣tural to wish to make his heart mine, as he seem'd himself ignorant of its value.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P:
I see she always lov'd him (aside). I find, Madam, you're already sensible of his worth, his
passion. How happy is my friend, to be the favou∣rite of one with such sense to distinguish merit, and such beauty to reward it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Your friend! Sir. What friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: My best friend—My friend Mr. Lofty, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: He, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Yes, he Madam. He is, indeed, what your warmest wishes might have form'd him. And to his other qualities, he adds that of the most pas∣sionate regard for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Amazement!—No more of this, I beg you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I see your confusion, Madam, and know how to interpret it. And since I so plainly read the language of your heart, shall I make my friend happy, by communicating your sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: By no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Excuse me; I must; I know you desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Mr. Honeywood, let me tell you, that you wrong my sentiments and yourself. When I first applied to your friendship, I expected advice and assistance; but now, Sir, I see that it is vain to ex∣pect happiness from him, who has been so bad an oeconomist of his own; and that I must disclaim his friendship, who ceases to be a friend to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: How is this! she has confessed she lov'd him, and yet she seemed to part in displeasure. Can I have done any thing to reproach myself with? No; I believe not; yet, after all, these things should not be done by a third person; I should have spared her confusion. My friendship carried me a little too far.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter CROAKER, with the letter in his hand, and Mrs. CROAKER.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! And so, my dear, it's your supreme wish that I should be quite wretched upon this occasion? Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: (Mimicking) Ha, ha, ha! and so my dear it's your supreme pleasure to give me no better con∣solation?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: Positively, my dear, what is this in∣cendiary stuff and trumpery to me. Our house may travel thro' the air like the house of Loretto, for ought I care, If I'm to be miserable in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Would to Heaven it were converted into an house of correction for your benefit. Have we not every thing to alarm us? Perhaps, this very mo∣ment the tragedy is beginning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: Then let us reserve our distress till the rising of the curtain, or give them the money they want, and have done with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Give them my money!—And pray, what right have they to my money?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: And pray, what right then have you to my good humour?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: And so your good humour advises me to part with my money? Why then, to tell your good humour a piece of my mind, I'd sooner part with my wife. Here's Mr. Honeywood, see what he'll say to it. My dear Honeywood, look at this incen∣diary letter dropped at my door. It will freeze you with terror; and yet lovey here can read it—Can read it, and laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: Yes, and so will Mr. Honeywood.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: If he does, I'll suffer to be hanged the next minute in the rogue's place, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: Speak, Mr. Honeywood; is there any thing more foolish than my husband's fright upon this occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: It would not become me to decide, Madam; but doubtless, the greatness of his terrors now, will but invite them to renew their villainy another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: I told you, he'd be of my opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P:
How, Sir! do you maintain that I should lie down under such an injury, and shew, neither by
my tears, or complaints, that I have something of the spirit of a man in me?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir. You ought to make the loudest complaints, if you desire redress. The surest way to have redress, is to be earnest in the pursuit of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Ay, whose opinion is he of now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: But don't you think that laughing off our fears is the best way?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: What is the best, Madam, few can say; but I'll maintain it to be a very wise way.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: But we're talking of the best. Surely the best way is to face the enemy in the field, and not wait till he plunders us in our very very bed-cham∣ber.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Why, Sir, as to the best, that—that's a very wise way too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: But can any thing be more absurd, than to double our distresses by our apprehensions, and put it in the power of every low fellow, that can scrawl ten words of wretched spelling, to torment us?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Without doubt, nothing more absurd.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: How! would it not be more absurd to despise the rattle till we are bit by the snake?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Without doubt, perfectly absurd.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Then you are of my opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: And you reject mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Heaven's forbid, Madam. No, sure no rea∣soning can be more just than yours. We ought cer∣tainly to dsepise malice if we cannot oppose it, and not make the incendiary's pen as fatal to our repose as the highwayman's pistol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: O! then you think I'm quite right?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Perfectly right.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: A plague of plagues, we can't be both right. I ought to be sorry, or I ought to be glad. My hat must be on my head, or my hat must be off.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker
SP.P: Certainly, in two opposite opinions, if one be perfectly reasonable, the other can't be per∣fectly right.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: And why may not both be right, Madam: Mr. Croaker in earnestly seeking redress, and you in waiting the event with good humour? Pray let me see the letter again. I have it. This letter requires twenty guineas to be left at the bar of the Talbot inn. If it be indeed an incendiary letter, what if you and I, Sir, go there; and, when the writer comes to be paid his expected booty, seize him?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: My dear friend its the very thing; the very thing. While I walk by the door, you shall plant yourself in ambush near the bar; burst out upon the miscreant like a masqued battery; extort a confession at once, and so hang him up by surprise.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Yes; but I would not chuse to exercise too much severity. It is my maxim, Sir, that crimes ge∣nerally punish themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Well, but we may upbraid him a little, I suppose? (Ironically.)

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Ay, but not punish him too rigidly.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Well, well, leave that to my own bene∣volence.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Well, I do: but remember that universal benevolence is the first law of nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Yes; and my universal benevolence will hang the dog, if he had as many necks as a hydra.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT THE FIFTH.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Well, we have got safe to the inn, how∣ever. Now, if the post-chaise were ready—

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: The horses are just finishing their oats; and, as they are not going to be married, they chuse to take their own time.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: You are for ever giving wrong motives to my impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Be as impatient as you will, the horses must take their own time; besides, you don't con∣sider, we have got no answer from our fellow tra∣veller yet. If we hear nothing from Mr. Leontine, we have only one way left us.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: What way?

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: The way home again.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Not so. I have made a resolution to go, and nothing shall induce me to break it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Ay; resolutions are well kept when they jump with inclination. However, I'll go hasten things without. And I'll call too at the bar to see if any thing should be left for us there. Don't be in such a plaguy hurry, Madam, and we shall go the faster, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: What! Solomon; why don't you move? Pipes and tobacco for the Lamb there.—Will no body answer? To the Dolphin; quick. The Angel has been outrageous this half hour. Did your lady∣ship call, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: No, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: I find, as you're for Scotland, Madam—But, that's no business of mine; married, or not mar∣ried, I ask no questions. To be sure, we had a sweet little couple set off from this two days ago for the same place. The Gentleman, for a Taylor, was, to be sure, as fine a spoken taylor, as ever blew froth from a full pot. And the young lady so bashful, it was near half an hour before we could get her to finish a pint of rasberry between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: But this gentleman and I are not going to be married, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: May be not. That's no business of mine; for certain, Scotch marriages seldom turn out. There was of my own knowledge, Miss Macfag, that married her father's footman.—Alack-a-day, she and her husband soon parted, and now keep separate cel∣lars in Hedge-Lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: A very pretty picture of what lies before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: My dear Olivia, my anxiety till you were out of danger, was too great to be resisted. I could not help coming to see you set out, tho' it exposes us to a discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: May every thing you do prove as fortunate. Indeed, Leontine, we have been most cruelly dis∣appointed. Mr. Honeywood's bill upon the city, has, it seems been protested, and we have been utterly at a loss how to proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: How! An offer of his own too. Sure, he could not mean to deceive us.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Depend upon his sincerity; he only mistook the desire for the power of serving us. But let us think no more of it. I believe the post-chaise is ready by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P:
Not quite yet! and, begging your ladyship's pardon, I don't think your ladyship quite ready for the post-chaise. The north road is a cold place, Madam. I have a drop in the house of as pretty
rasberry as ever was tipt over tongue. Just a thimble full to keep the wind off your stomach. To be sure, the last couple we had here, they said it was a perfect nosegay. Ecod, I sent them both away as good na∣tur'd—Up went the blinds, round went the wheels, and drive away post-boy, was the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Well, while my friend Honeywood is upon the post of danger at the bar, it must be my business to have an eye about me here. I think I know an incendiary's look; for, wherever the devil makes a purchase, he never fails to set his mark. Ha! who have we here? My son and daughter! What can they be doing here!

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: I tell you, Madam, it will do you good; I think I know by this time what's good for the north road. It's a raw night, Madam.—Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Not a drop more, good Madam. I should now take it as a greater favour, if you hasten the horses, for I am afraid to be seen myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Landlady.
SP.P: That shall be done. Wha, Solomon! are you all dead there? Wha, Solomon, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Well; I dread, lest an expedition begun in fear, should end in repentance.—Every moment we stay increases our danger, and adds to my appre∣hensions.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: There's no danger, trust me, my dear; there can be none: if Honeywood has acted with honour, and kept my father, as he promised, in employment till we are out of danger, nothing can interrupt our journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: I have no doubt of Mr. Honeywood's sin∣cerity, and even his desires to serve us. My fears are from your father's suspicions. A mind so dispos∣ed to be alarmed without a cause, will be but too ready when there's a reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P:
Why, let him, when we are out of his power. But, believe me, Olivia, you have no great
reason to dread his resentment. His repining tem∣per, as it does no manner of injury to himself, so will it never do harm to others. He only frets to keep himself employed, and scolds for his private amuse∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: I don't know that; but, I'm sure, on some occasions, it makes him look most shockingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: (Discovering himself) How does he look now?—How does he look now?

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: How do I look now? Sir, I am your very humble servant. Madam, I am your's. What, you are going off, are you? Then, first, if you please, take a word or two from me with you before you go. Tell me first where you are going? and when you have told me that, perhaps, I shall know as little as I did before.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: If that be so, our answer might but increase your displeasure, without adding to your information.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: I want no information from you, puppy: and you too, good Madam, what answer have you got. Eh (a cry without, stop him). I think I heard a noise. My friend, Honeywood, without—has he seized the incendiary? Ah, no, for now I heard no more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Honeywood, without! Then, Sir, it was Mr. Honeywood that directed you hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: No, Sir, it was Mr. Honeywood conduct∣ed me hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Possible! Why, he's in the house now, Sir. More anxious about me, than my own son, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Then, Sir, he's a villian.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: How, sirrah! a villian, because he takes most care of your father? I'll not bear it. I tell you I'll not bear it. Honeywood is a friend to the family, and I'll have him treated as such.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: I shall study to repay his friendship as it deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Ah, rogue, If you knew how earnestly he entered into my griefs, and pointed out the means to detect them, you would love him as I do. (A cry without stop him) Fire and fury! they have seized the incendiary: they have the villian, the incendiary in view. Stop him, stop an incendiary, a murderer; stop him.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Oh, my terrors! What can this new tu∣mult mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Some new mark, I suppose, of Mr Honey∣wood's sincerity. But we shall have satisfaction: he shall give me instant satissaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: It must not be, my Leontine, if you value my esteem, or my happiness. Whatever be our fate, let us not add guilt to our misfortunes—Consider that our innocence will shortly be all we have left us. You must forgive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Forgive him! Has he not in every instance betrayed us? Forced me to borrow money from him, which appears a mere trick to delay us: pro∣mised to keep my father engaged till we were out of danger, and here brought him to the very scene of our escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Don't be precipitate. We may yet be mistaken.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter POSTBOY, dragging in JARVIS: HONEYWOOD entering soon after.

SP.SPEAKER: Postboy.
SP.P: Ay, master, we have him fast enough. Here is the incendiary dog. I'm entitled to the re∣ward; I'll take my oath I saw him ask for the money at the bar, and then run for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Come, bring him along. Let us see him. Let him learn to blush for his crimes. (Discovering his mistake). Death! what's here! Jarvis, Leontine, Olivia! What can all this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: Why, I'll tell you what it means: that I was an old fool, and that you are my master—that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I find you have kept your word with me. After such baseness, I wonder how you can venture to see the man you have injured.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: My dear Leontine, by my life, my ho∣nour—

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Peace, peace, for shame; and do not con∣tinue to aggravate baseness by hypocrisy. I know you Sir, I know you.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Why, wont you hear me! By all that's just, I knew not—

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: Hear you, Sir! to what purpose? I now see through all your low arts; your ever complying with every opinion; your never refusing any request; your friendship as common as a prostitute's favours, and as fallacious; all these, Sir, have long been con∣temptible to the world, and are now perfectly so to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Ha! contemptible to the world! That reaches me. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: All the seeming sincerity of your professions I now find were only allurements to betray; and all your seeming regret for their consequences, only cal∣culated to cover the cowardice of your heart. Draw, villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Where is the villain? Where is the in∣cendiary? (seizing the post-boy.) Hold him fast, the dog; he has the gallows in his face. Come, you dog, confess; confess all, and hang yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Post-Boy.
SP.P: Zounds! Master, what do you throttle me for?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: (Beating him.) Dog, do you resist; do you resist?

SP.SPEAKER: Post-Boy.
SP.P: Zounds! Master, I'm not he; there's the man that we thought was the rogue, and turns out to be one of the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Mr. Croaker, we have all been under a strange mistake here; I find there is nobody guilty; it was all an error; entirely an error of our own.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: And I say, Sir, that you're in an error; for there's guilt and double guilt, a plot, a damn'd jesuitical pestilential plot, and I must have proof of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Do but hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: What, you intend to bring'em off, I sup∣pose; I'll hear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Madam, you seem at least calm enough to hear reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Good Jarvis, let me then explain it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jarvis.
SP.P: What signifies explanations, when the thing is done?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Will nobody hear me? Was there ever such a set, so blinded by passion and prejudice! (To the Post-Boy.) My good friend, I believe you'll be surprized when I assure you—

SP.SPEAKER: Post-Boy.
SP.P: Sure me nothing—I'm sure of nothing but a good beating.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Come then, you, Madam, if you ever hope for any favour or forgiveness, tell me sincerely all you know of this affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Unhappily, Sir, I'm but too much the cause of your suspicions: you see before you, Sir, one that with false pretences has stept into your fa∣mily to betray it: not your daughter—

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Not my daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Olivia.
SP.P: Not your daughter—but a mean deceiver—who—support me, I cannot—

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Help, she's going, give her air.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Ay, ay; take the young woman to the air, I would not hurt a hair of her head, whose ever daughter she may be—not so bad as that neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P:
Yes, yes, all's out; I now see the whole affair: my son is either married, or going to be so,
to this lady, whom he imposed upon me as his sister. Ay, certainly so; and yet I don't find it afflicts me so much as one might think. There's the advantage of fretting away our misfortunes beforehand, we never feel them when they come.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Miss RICHLAND and SIR WILLIAM.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: But how do you know, Madam, that my nephew intends setting off from this place?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: My maid assured me he was come to this inn, and my own knowledge of his intending to leave the kingdom, suggested the rest. But what do I see, my guardian here before us! Who, my dear Sir, could have expected meeting you here; to what accident do we owe this pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: To a fool, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: But to what purpose did you come?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: To play the fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: But with whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: With greater fools than myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Explain.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Why, Mr. Honeywood brought me here, to do nothing now I am here; and my son is going to be married to I don't know who that is here; so now you are as wise as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Married! to whom, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: To Olivia; my daughter, as I took her to be; but who the devil she is, or whose daughter she is, I know no more than the man in the moon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Then, Sir, I can inform you; and, tho' a stranger, yet you shall find me a friend to your fa∣mily: it will be enough at present, to assure you, that, both in point of birth and fortune, the young lady is at least your son's equal. Being left by her father, Sir James Woodville—

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Sir James Woodville! What, of the West?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Being left by him, I say, to the care of a mercenary wretch, whose only aim was to secure her fortune to himself, she was sent into France, under pretence of education; and there every art
was tried to fix her for life in a convent, contrary to her inclinations. Of this I was informed upon my arrival at Paris; and, as I had been once her father's friend, I did all in my power to frustrate her guardi∣an's base intentions. I had even meditated to rescue her from his authority, when your son stept in with more pleasing violence, gave her liberty, and you a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: But I intend to have a daughter of my own chusing, Sir. A young lady, Sir, whose for∣tune, by my interest with those that have interest, will be double what my son has a right to expect. Do you know Mr. Lofty, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; and know that you are de∣ceived in him. But step this way, and I'll convince you.
SP.STAGE: [Croaker and Sir William seem to confer.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Obstinate man, still to persist in his out∣rage! Insulted by him, despis'd by all, I now be∣gin to grow contemptible, even to myself. How have I sunk by too great an assiduity to please! How have I overtax'd all my abilities, lest the approbation of a single fool should escape me! But all is now over; I have survived my reputation, my fortune, my friendships, and nothing remains henceforward for me but solitude and repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Is it true, Mr. Honeywood, that you are setting off, without taking leave of your friends? The report is, that you are quitting England. Can it be?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Yes, Madam; and tho' I am so unhappy as to have fallen under your displeasure, yet, thank Heaven, I leave you to happiness; to one who loves you, and deserves your love; to one who has power to procure you affluence, and generosity to improve your enjoyment of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: And are you sure, Sir, that the gentle∣man you mean is what you describe him?

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: I have the best assurances of it, his serving me. He does indeed deserve the highest happiness, and that is in your power to confer. As for me! weak and wavering as I have been, obliged by all, and incapable of serving any, what happiness can I find but in solitude? What hope but in being for∣gotten?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: A thousand! to live among friends that esteem you, whose happiness it will be to be permitted to oblige you.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: No, Madam; my resolution is fix'd. In∣feriority among strangers is easy; but among those that once were equals, insupportable. Nay, to shew you how far my resolution can go, I can now speak with calmness of my former follies, my vanity, my dissipation, my weakness. I will even confess, that, among the number of my other presumptions, I had the insolence to think of loving you. Yes, Madam, while I was pleading the passion of another, my heart was tortur'd with its own. But it is over, it was unworthy our friendship, and let it be forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: You amaze me!

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: But you'll forgive it, I know you will; since the confession should not have come from me even now, but to convince you of the sincerity of my intention of—never mentioning it more.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Stay, Sir, one moment—Ha! he here—

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Is the coast clear? None but friends? I have followed you here with a trifling piece of intelligence: but it goes no farther, things are not yet ripe for a discovery. I have spirits working at a certain board; Your affair at the treasury will be done in less than—a thousand years, Mum!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: Sooner, Sir, I should hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Why, yes, I believe it may, if it falls into proper hands, that know where to push and where to parry; that know how the land lies—eh, Honeywood.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: It is sallen into yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Well, to keep you no longer in suspense, your thing is done. It is done, I say—that's all. I have just had assurances from Lord Neverout, that the claim has been examined, and found admissible. Quietus is the word, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: But how! his Lordship has been at New∣market these ten days.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Indeed! Then Sir Gilbert Goose must have been most damnably mistaken. I had it of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: He! why Sir Gilbert and his family have been in the country this month.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: This month! It must certainly be so—Sir Gilbert's Letter did come to me from Newmarket, so that he must have met his Lordship there; and so it came about. I have his letter about me, I 'll read it to you. (Taking out a large bundle.) That's from Paoli of Corsica, that from the Marquis of Squi∣lachi.—Have you a mind to see a letter from Count Poniatowski, now King of Poland—Honest Pon—
O, Sir, what are you here too? I'll tell you what, honest friend, if you have not absolutely delivered my letter to Sir William Honeywood, you may re∣turn it. The thing will do without him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Sir, I have delivered it, and must inform you, it was received with the most mortifying con∣tempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Contempt! Mr. Lofty, what can that mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Let him go on, let him go on, I say. You'll find it come to something presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I believe you'll be amazed, if, after waiting some time in the anti-chamber, after being surveyed with insolent curiosity by the passing servants, I was at last assured, that Sir William Honeywood knew no such person, and I must cer∣tainly have been imposed upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Good; let me die, very good. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Now, for my life, I can't find out half the goodness of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: You can't. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: No, for the soul of me; I think it was as confounded a bad answer, as ever was sent from one private gentleman to another.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: And so you can't find out the force of the message? Why I was in the house at that very time. Ha! ha! It was I that sent that very answer to my own letter. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Indeed! How! why!

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: In one word, things between Sir William and me must be behind the curtain. A party has many eyes. He sides with Lord Buzzard, I side with Sir Gilbert Goose. So that unriddles the mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: And so it does indeed, and all my suspi∣cions are over.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Your suspicions! What then you have been suspecting, you have been suspecting, have you? Mr. Croaker, you and I were friends, we are friends no longer. Never talk to me. It's over; I say, it's over.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: As I hope for your favour, I did not mean to offend. It escaped me. Don't be discomposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Zounds, Sir, but I am discomposed, and will be discomposed. To be treated thus! Who am I! Was it for this I have been dreaded both by inns and outs! Have I been libelled in the Gazetteer, and praised in the St. James's; have I been chaired at Wildman's, and a speaker at Merchant Taylor's Hall; have I had my hand to addresses, and my head in the print-shops, and talk to me of suspects!

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: My dear Sir, be pacified. What can you have but asking pardon?

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Sir, I will not be pacified—Suspects! Who am I! To be used thus, have I paid court to men in favour to serve my friends, the Lords of the Treasury, Sir William Honeywood, and the rest of the gang, and talk to me of suspects! Who am I, I say, who am I!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Since, Sir, you're so pressing for an an∣swer, I'll tell you who you are. A gentleman, as well acquainted with politics, as with men in power;
as well acquainted with persons of fashion, as with modesty; with Lords of the Treasury, as with truth; and with all, as you are with Sir William Honeywood. I am Sir William Honeywood.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Sir William Honeywood!

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Astonishment! my uncle!

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: So then my confounded genius has been all this time only leading me up to the garret, in order to fling me out of the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: What, Mr. Importance, and are these your works? Suspect you! You who have been dreaded by the inns and outs: you who have had your hand to addresses, and your head stuck up in print-shops. If your were served right, you should have your head stuck up in the pillory.

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P: Ay, stick it where you will, for, by the Lord, it cuts but a very poor figure where it sticks at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Croaker, I hope you now see how incapable this gentleman is of serving you, and how little Miss Richland has to expect from his in∣fluence.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Ay, Sir, too well I see it, and I can't but say I have had some boding of it these ten days. So I'm resolved, since my son has placed his affecti∣ons on a lady of moderate fortune, to be satisfied with his choice, and not run the hazard of another Mr. Lofty, in helping him to a better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I approve your resolution, and here they come, to receive a confirmation of your pardon and consent.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Mrs. CROAKER, JARVIS, LEONTINE, OLIVIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Croaker.
SP.P: Where's my husband! Come, come, lovely, you must forgive them. Jarvis here has been to tell me the whole affair; and, I say, you must forgive them. Our own was a stolen match, you know, my dear; and we never had any reason to repent of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: I wish we could both say so: however, this gentleman, Sir William Honeywood, has been beforehand with you, in obtaining their pardon. So, if the two poor fools have a mind to marry, I think, we can tack them together without crossing the Tweed for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leont.
SP.P: How blest, and unexpected! What, what can we say to such goodness! But our future obedi∣ence shall be the best reply. And, as for this gentle∣man, to whom we owe—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Excuse me, Sir, if I interrupt your thanks, as I have here an interest that calls me. (Turning to Honeywood.) Yes, Sir, you are surprised to see me; and I own that a desire of correcting your follies led me hither. I saw, with indignation, the errors of a mind that only sought applause from others; that easiness of disposition, which, tho' inclin'd to the right, had not courage to condemn the wrong. I saw with regret those splendid errors, that still took name from some neighbouring duty. Your charity, that was but injustice; your benevolence, that was but weakness; and your friendship but credulity. I saw, with regret, great talents and extensive learning, only employed to add sprightliness to error, and encrease your perplexities. I saw your mind with a thousand natural charms: but the greatness of its beauty served only to heighten my pity for its prostitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Cease to upbraid me, Sir; I have for some time but too strongly felt the justice of your repoaches. But there is one way still left me. Yes, Sir, I have determined, this very hour, to quit for ever a place where I have made myself the voluntary slave of all; and to seek among strangers that fortitude which may give strength to the mind, and marshal all its diffipated virtues. Yet, ere I depart, permit me to solicit fa∣vour for this gentleman; who, notwithstanding what has happened, has laid me under the most signal obli∣gations. Mr. Lofty—

SP.SPEAKER: Lofty.
SP.P:
Mr. Honeywood, I'm resolv'd upon a re∣formation, as well as you. I now begin to find, that
the man who first invented the art of speaking truth was a much cunninger fellow than I thought him. And to prove that I design to speak truth for the fu∣ture, I must now assure you, that you owe your late enlargement to another; as, upon my soul, I had no hand in the matter. So now, if any of the company has a mind for preferment, he may take my place. I'm determined to resign.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: How have I been deceived!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No, Sir, you have been obliged to a kinder, fairer friend for that favour. To Miss Rich∣land. Would she complete our joy, and make the man she has honoured by her friendship happy in her love, I should then forget all, and be as blest as the welfare of my dearest kinsman can make me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Rich.
SP.P: After what is past, it would be but affectation to pretend to indifference. Yes, I will own an attachment, which, I find, was more than friendship. And if my intreaties cannot alter his resolution to quit the country; I will even try, if my hand has not power to detain him.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P: Heavens! how can I have deserved all this? How express my happiness, my gratitude! A moment, like this, over-pays an age of apprehen∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: Croaker.
SP.P: Well, now I see content in every face; but Heaven send we be all better this day three months.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Henceforth, nephew, learn to respect yourself. He who seeks only for applause from without, has all his happiness in another's keep∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Honeyw.
SP.P:
Yes, Sir, I now too plainly perceive my errors. My vanity, in attempting to please all, by fearing to offend any. My meanness in approving
folly, lest fools should disapprove. Henceforth, there∣fore, it shall be my study to reserve my pity for real distress; my friendship for true merit, and my love for her, who first taught me what it is to be happy.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE,
DIV1.L: AS puffing quacks some caitiff wretch procure
To swear the pill, or drop, has wrought a cure;
Thus on the stage, our play-wrights still depend
For Epilogues and Prologues on some friend,
Who knows each art of coaxing up the town,
And make full many a bitter pill go down.
Conscious of this, our bard has gone about,
And teaz'd each rhyming friend to help him out.
An Epilogue, things can't go on without it;
It cou'd not fail, wou'd you but set about it.
Young man, cries one (a bard laid up in clover)
Alas, young man, my writing days are over;
Let boys play tricks, and kick the straw, not I;
Your brother Doctor there, perhaps, may try.
What Il dear Sir, the Doctor interposes,
What plant my thistle, Sir, among his roses!
No, no, I've other contests to maintain;
To-night I head our troops at Warwick-Lane.
Go, ask your manager—Who, me? your pardon;
Those things are not our fort at Covent-Garden.
Our Author's friends, thus plac'd at happy distance,
Gives him good words indeed, but no assistance.
As some unhappy wight, at some new play,
At the Pit door stands elbowing away,
While oft, with many a smile, and many a shrug,
He eyes the centre, where his friends sit snug,
His simpering friends, with pleasure in their eyes,
Sink as he sinks, and as he rises rise:
He nods, they nod; he cringes, they grimace;
But not a soul will budge to give him place.
Since then, unhelp'd, our bard must now conform
To 'bide the pelting of this pittiless storm,
Blame where you must, be candid where you can,
And view with favour, the Good-natur'd Man.
